Tuesday was one of the nicest days I can remember having in a long, long time...perhaps even the nicest day I've ever had here in San Francisco...it's funny because I really didn't do anything great at all...went to Golden Gate Park in the afternoon...found a nice spot near a pond - ducks, tortoises, pigeons, flowers, trees, clear sunny sky...put a blanket down and just laid there for hours drifting in and out of my slumber while Iris read a book...opened my eyes and saw a squirrel scamper right up to me, stopping a few times to stare before coming closer still...it came all the way up to me and touched my hand which had been extended out, then ran away...felt like I was in some Disney cartoon...it went down towards a bench where 2 dudes were sitting and it jumped onto the back of the chair...the guy turned around and freaked, which was the funniest thing ever! big muscular run literally jumping out of his seat because of a squirrel...I laughed 'til tears came running down my face...around 6pm, and we're still lying there, I hear a sound so I open my eyes and what do I see? 2 feet away from me is a fox! it was standing there just looking at us...I woke Iris up, and she got the shock of her life...the fox then walked away a few steps, stopped looked at us again, walked away some more then stopped to look at us again before disappearing into the bushes...didn't even know there were foxes in SF...do believe its the first time I've seen one in the flesh/fur...around 6.30 it started getting cold so we packed up...as I'm folding the blanket, Iris runs down to the pond and starts chasing the ducks and pigeons...chasing the way only little kids do, running to the left, then right, flapping her arms about and trying to actually catch one...smiled for a bit then wondered whatever happened to MY inner child? being so jaded and cynical myself,it was nice to know that there are still people like that in the world...and that was my day...funny how a day of nothing can be so amusing...maybe i'm just getting old..and soft...oh well..que sera sera...

when i was very young, the one thing that drove me towards having dreams/ambitions or even finding out what that meant was just to prove to my father that i could be better than him. that i was infact better than him. my father wasnt the toyads, ramly's or amminuddins of this universe. infact if you called the affectionate and supportive section of the universe, he wouldnt be there. at least he wouldnt be there for me. he was always too busy with his students or was always so absored with the only thing that seemed to matter...st johns, that he didnt have time for anything else..for me. so i knew that whatever i did in life, it would be so that i wouldn't be him. i would do more with my life, i would travel, i would love and be loved, especially by my family, and most of all i would inspire those around me. it didnt have to be big, but it had to mean something to someone. its been a while since i've thought about all that. i haven't revisited the hatred i kept for my dad, for a long time now. i havent buried it either, but i'm lucky i've been busy, and havent had the time to think about it. infact although our relationship has improved since i got married, i've just been too lazy to 'update' how i feel about my dad now. too lazy to think about it. until last saturday. i had an outdoor shoot at a vintage car show. i was with my producer joe jer when i met one of joshua's friends. joe jer's convinced that i know the entire KL.. the truth is most of them are from st john's so they know me. anyway, he introduced me to the other car owners and i started talking to this weird looking guy. half way through our conversation joshua's friend said "this is 'vincent's daughter', and then the conversation just stirred towards my dad and st johns (JOY). he couldnt stop talking to me. it felt weird not because it hadnt happen before- quite the contrary, people seem to feel like they have to say something to me - but because i didnt particularyly like discussing about my father. then in the blur of what he was saying, he said "your dad really meant something to us". i snapped out of my own thoughts and really looked at him... "who was this guy".. and then it didnt matter. for the first time in a long time i was forced to think about what he said and what that meant to me. i realised that the man i thought of as self absorbed and cold for all these years, was to this man, an inspiration.who would have thought. still - i dont know how i feel about it all. but one thing is for sure, if some years from now a complete stranger told my kids that i meant something to them, i would have at come close to being what he was to others.

I’m one of those people who hide the fact that I like fussing over my appearance. Infact when I’m applying lipstick in the ladies before I leave work, and someone barges in, I get embarrassed and try to quickly hide my lipstick. Almost like I don’t want to admit that my lips arent naturally rosy :). However, that being said, I also don’t like spending too much time on how I look and because of that; I like to give myself limits on what I would do. eg, I don’t mind the occasional visit to the hairdressers to get a trim or wash etc, or the when-I-have-money trip to the nail studio and only lipstick/blusher during weekdays. But recently Shasha’s been bugging me about getting my upper lip hairs removed. Actually she’s been bugging me for quite a while now. And to tell you the truth, I didn’t even notice that people were removing their upper lip hairs until she brought it to my attention. I mean why bother and serious who cares. So no matter how persistent she was I didn’t relent. It hadn’t been an issue before and I will not let it bother me now. I will not succumb to yet another one of society’s necessary ‘do’s’. Unfortunately God put a certain woman by the name of Aunty Viji in my life. And she has the thickest mustache I’ve ever seen on a woman.I've known her since I was a kid, but I hadnt seen her since I was about 10 and coincidentally I bumped into her recently. She really is the nicest person in the world, but God, that mustache! I try not to look at it whenever we speak, but my eyes just cant keep away. Those things are like a fridge and me; magnets. So today, virgin ‘threadee’ me went down to Bangsar. Put 20 cents in the meter and that bought me 15 minutes. (who says you can't buy time) Went in and the lady wasn’t there yet so I had to wait. Fortunately I met Shasha's cousin Amee there. Go figure - her family must be the reason that place is expanding. Amee talked me through the process –she’s been there many times apparently. The 'thread lady' walked in 15 minutes later and I was 5th in line. Nobody yelled out in pain so I didn’t think it was going to be that bad. Finally I sit in the chair, tilt my head back and shut my eyes. Suddenly I feel this mini lawnmower on my upper lip. *OUCH* it fuckin' hurt man! And I tell you it’s a lie when they say it only takes 'a moment', because it felt like forever. I was still wincing in pain and about to get off my seat when she proceeded to do my eyebrows. *OUUCH. MOTHE F%^&*$*. I guess because I didn’t say anything she thought I wanted them done too. There were tears people! I got off the seat and looked in the mirror expecting to seem my eyebrows all thin and weird but instead I was impressed. It actually looked good. Infact they were perfect, better than anything I’d ever done. And even though it feels like my upper lip is wider now because it’s lost all its cover, it isn’t. And yes, I know that besides Shasha, I will probably be the only one who will notice the difference. Still it made me feel good. Unfortunately, it’s the start of a routine I will be forced to keep up every week or so. Luckily it only costs RM8. ( that is, minus the parking ticket I got cause my meter ran out)

When I was a young and depressed teenage who rarely smiled, I used to picture another me. One who had friends. One who smiled alot. One who had a fun job that some (not all - i know, they've got better jobs - sigh) would envy. One who would have people think about her once in a while and call her when they do. One who would get invited to things not because the other party's parents forced them into. One who would...shit, I could go on. I think I've sort of become her - the other me. But I'm not sure if I like her... yet. There was another teenager that I knew way back when who was more down in the dumps than I could ever be. I don't what she did, but the last time I saw her she laughed and smiled along with me. She would even take a compliment without making three insulting comments about herself to cancel the good one. Sometime last week she emailed me photos of her party trip to Vegas. There was a beautiful girl there who looked like she enjoyed life, and some that it had to offer her. She looked like that other me I pictured when I was younger except that she didn't have my face. She had the face of a friend of mine I call Harps. I didn't think it could be her because the teenager that I knew loved to slouch and looked as if everything she looked at, from a rainbow to a rat in Bangsar, depressed her. This girl was standing a little straighter and looked very confident. Harps is a wonderful writer - slightly scattered at times, and an amazing artist. I am not in the know of anything to do with art nor am I a big fan of it. I am however a big fan of beautiful paintings that sometimes speak to me. And one of her paintings did. At that same time, she and I were working out unresolved issues. In my silent apology for any hurt I caused her, I wrote an article about her (it was fun interview done on our backs in her bedroom) accompanied by a picture featuring the painting that spoke to me. A girl sitting on the floor in a corner of a tiled room...alone. Like the old me, thinking that the world offered nothing that suited me. Like the old her, that knew that sometimes the world couldn't give her what she needed. Today she's stepped out into her own. Maybe a little dazed and confused by the Californian sun but she's a member of life as she wants it to be - save for getting a job maybe?
